Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2010 06:55AM JennGrace wrote: Thanks everyone for the wonderful posts!  Your replies have helped me tremendously in making my decision -- I faxed my portion of the application after having a heart-to-heart talk with my oncologist's nurse practitioner.  She said that initially she had written down what they think my life expectancy is but she said she didn't know that I would want her to write down 6 mos. to a year due to benefits purposes.  She said it was no biggie so I resent her the blank forms and she'll forward everything to my HR.  Whew!  Now I can pay off our bills/loans, go on a vacation and have some more left for that rainy day. I also found out from the insurance company that they will continue to pay for the premiums after I have collected the benefits.  I have to fill out what they call a waiver of payment of premiums.  Another plus! wayover20 - Can you elaborate on what you stated about your house will be paid off when you die?  You mentioned that because it is insured.  I'm asking because the first thing I want to do is pay off the mortgage, a few line of credits, one car, and purchase a home and put a huge downpayment on it.  This home will be a rental property so that my husband and my daughter will have that 'extra'  income for themselves (or for me too!).
Posts.Title: Accelerated benefits - Have you considered withdrawing? JennGrace vickib

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2010 06:55AM JennGrace wrote: wayover20- yes I think PIP means private insurance payment? I think..
Posts.Title: Accelerated benefits - Have you considered withdrawing? JennGrace vickib

Posts.Content: JennGrace wrote: Since this is the Stage IV forum, I figured this is the most appropriate area to post this question.  I have started to complete an application for withdrawing accelerated benefits from my life insurance through work.  After my oncologist completed their part, I still have to complete my part.  Well I browsed through the Internet and found that usually insurance companies only pay when the claimant has less than one year expectancy.  Woah!  After my husband and I calcuated where we would like the money to go, I decided to postpone sending in my section of the application. My oncologist is not into statistics so he doesn't give the actual survival prognosis for a patient (well at least this is what I heard). So it's just a matter of him writing on paper about my life expectancy and being done with it.  I'm not big on statistics either because I know only God knows of my expiration date.  However, I'm having second thoughts whether I want that chunk of money, feel good that the house will be paid off and then go to Disney this year- and knowing in the back of my mind what the doctor wrote down. What are your thoughts ladies? Dx 6/23/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2010 11:25PM - edited Apr 4, 2010 11:28PM by JennGrace I am so happy to read all the ladies that have benefited from my post - and I originally thought it was a stupid inquiry!  To give an update on everyone -- our house is paid off, along with our only credit card loan, a hospital bill (got a payoff discount of 50%), grad school loan (another 50% discount off), possibly a car loan (still thinking of this one).. Ladies, do look into getting what is called an early payoff discount for some of your bills/loans.  I am a business woman by trade so I either wrote a letter or called my creditors/banks and bargained for the best deal.  I started my speech with "I have been deemed disabled by Social Security Admin, how can I request for a loan/bill write-off?"  Once they told me they don't offer this, then I ask for a the early payoff discount.  I paid off most of our bills with a 50% early payment discount.  I love it!  Oh yes, I have also put money aside for 6 months for that 'rainy' day, also some money for a vacation and the rest we are putting away on a CD or something.  Also, I have put aside money for church or charity or something.

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2010 11:16PM JennGrace wrote: Hi I just finished Abraxane/Avastin from Aug 2009 to Dec 2009 and had great shrinkage in the tumors in my liver and stability n my bones.  The sides effects I experienced were tearing of the eyes, some blurry vision, constant running of the nose, rectal bleeding, constipation, some tingling in my fingers.  I didn't experience any fatigue (luckily I never do with any chemo!) but I had problems sleeping (although I can't pinpoint if this is from this combo).  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Anyone on Abraxane/Avastin jneumann anamary1
